decisions.title: Work-Study Balance
decisions.scenario: You're taking 15 credits at HVCC and working 25 hours/week at Target. Your manager just offered you full-time hours at $16/hr, but it conflicts with your Tuesday/Thursday classes.
decisions.context_info: Working full-time while in school can earn you more money now, but might delay your degree. Community college students who work over 20 hours have lower graduation rates.

choices.label: üìö Keep school schedule, decline extra hours

immediate_outcome.text: You kept your Tuesday/Thursday classes. Your income stays the same at around $400/week part-time.

delayed_consequence.text: You finished your first year with good grades (3.4 GPA). You qualified for a scholarship that covers $1,500 of next year's tuition. Your manager respects your commitment to school.
delayed_consequence.why: Staying focused on school kept your grades up, which opened doors to financial aid. Employers value dedication even when you say no.

choices.label: üí∞ Take full-time hours, drop Thursday classes

immediate_outcome.text: You're now working 40 hours/week at $16/hr. Your paychecks are about $640/week after taxes. Feels good to have money.

delayed_consequence.text: You made good money but failed two classes from exhaustion. You need to retake them in summer ($800 each). Your degree is now delayed by a year. Total cost: $1,600 extra + lost time.
delayed_consequence.why: Working full-time while in school seems smart for money now, but failing classes costs more in the long run. You paid twice for the same education.

choices.label: ü§ù Negotiate: Work weekends only, keep classes

immediate_outcome.text: You proposed working Friday-Sunday full shifts. Your manager agreed! You'll work 24 hours on weekends at $17/hr (weekend differential).

delayed_consequence.text: You finished the year with a 3.2 GPA and consistent income. You're tired on weekends, but you protected your education. Your manager promoted you to weekend supervisor (+$1/hr raise).
delayed_consequence.why: Negotiating showed maturity. You found a solution that met both needs. Employers respect problem-solvers.

decisions.title: Student Loans
decisions.scenario: Your financial aid doesn't cover everything. You need $3,000 for next year's tuition. You can take federal student loans at 5% interest, or put it on a credit card at 22% interest to 'build credit.'
decisions.context_info: Student loans have lower interest rates and don't require payments until after graduation. Credit cards charge much higher interest and require monthly payments immediately.

immediate_outcome.text: You filled out the loan paperwork. The $3,000 is deposited directly to HVCC. No payments due until 6 months after graduation.

delayed_consequence.text: You graduated! Your loan balance is $3,158 (original $3,000 + interest during school). Your monthly payment will be $35/month for 10 years. Manageable on your new salary.
delayed_consequence.why: Federal loans have low rates and don't require payments during school. You used debt wisely for education that increased your earning power.

choices.label: üí≥ Put it on credit card to build credit

immediate_outcome.text: You charged $3,000 to your new credit card. The school got paid. Your minimum payment is $90/month.

delayed_consequence.text: You've been making minimum payments. Your balance is now $4,200 (original $3,000 + $1,200 interest). You're paying $90/month but the balance barely moves. This will take 6 years to pay off at this rate.
delayed_consequence.why: Credit cards are the most expensive way to pay for education. The 22% interest meant you paid $1,200 extra for the same tuition. Student loans would have cost $158 extra.

decisions.title: Emergency Fund
decisions.scenario: You got a $800 holiday bonus from Target. Your friends want to split an Airbnb in Montreal for New Year's ($200/person). You also need new tires ($400). You have $50 in savings.
decisions.context_info: Emergency funds protect you from unexpected costs. Financial experts recommend 3-6 months of expenses saved, but even $500 helps avoid debt when surprises happen.

choices.label: üéâ Go to Montreal, deal with tires later

immediate_outcome.text: Montreal was amazing! You spent $200 on the trip plus $150 on meals/drinks. You have $450 left from your bonus.

delayed_consequence.text: You got a flat tire driving to work. Your tires were too worn to patch it safely. You needed all 4 tires ($400) plus towing ($75). You had to put $25 on a credit card. Now you're stressed about that payment.
delayed_consequence.why: Fun now, stress later. If you'd handled the need (tires) before the want (trip), you'd have saved the towing cost and avoided credit card debt.

immediate_outcome.text: You got 4 new tires ($400). Your car is safe and reliable. You have $400 left from your bonus. Your friends are disappointed but understand.

delayed_consequence.text: Your car has been reliable. You saved that $400 and added another $200 from paychecks. You now have $600 in emergency savings. When your laptop died, you could afford to fix it ($150) without stress.
delayed_consequence.why: Handling needs before wants builds security. You avoided debt, kept your car safe, and started an emergency fund that saved you when the next surprise hit.
